Journal Title: Global South, The
Article Title: “France: Noriega to Be Extradited.”
Publisher: Duke University Press
Issue: globalsouth.6.issue-2
Date: Nov. 23, 2007
Author(s): Davidson Emily F.
Abstract: Public history sites like the West Indian Museum of Panama and the Miraflores Visitors Center have different approaches to narrating the Panama Canal story, ranging from tales of man’s triumph over nature and celebratory discourses of nationalist victories, to testimonies of the racial histories silenced by official renderings of the past. Given the important role of museums as educational institutions, sites that inform public opinion, and representational platforms for national tourism, this article explores the relationship these institutions forge between visitors and canal history. Through a comparative analysis of the narratives and experiential strategies at each site, I evaluate the degree to which Panamanians are cast as spectators in grandiose histories of triumph, or as agents, responsible for shaping the past, present and future. In contrast to these physical sites, I consider how The Society of Friends of the West Indian Museum of Panama constructs a living past through memory practices that challenge the petrified histories traditionally found in museums.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.2979/globalsouth.6.2.130 journal-article-10.2979_globalsouth.6.2.130.xml

Journal Title: Comparative Literature Studies
Article Title: Poetry Is Theft
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: complitstudies.51.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2014
Abstract: Like Hayes's “Snow for Wallace Stevens,” “Thirteen Ways of Looking at Blackbird (After Wallace Stevens)” by Olive Senior, a Jamaican poet living in Canada, reimagines the blackbird as an enslaved African arriving in the Americas. In addition to the obvious constraint of following a thirteen-part, meditative structure, each of Senior's sections picks up and revises select elements from the corresponding sections of Stevens's poem. Where Stevens in section IV offers a non-dualist philosophy (“A man and a woman / Are one. / A man and a woman and a blackbird / Are one”), Senior's poem offers a more jagged portrait, in which Blackbird, arriving on a sugarcane plantation, “no longer knows / if he is man or woman or bird or simply is” (IV). Abased and enslaved, a “survivor of the crossing,” Blackbird is “the lucky one in three” (II), exhausted and without the luxury to contemplate in tranquility, as does Stevens's poetic speaker (“I was of three minds,” II). Senior's rewriting changes how we read Stevens. When turning back to Stevens, the reader will hear Senior's resonances. Senior doesn't call Stevens a “foe,” but the implicit comparison—her corrective to the narrative—makes clear her position as she inscribes America's violent history of slavery into Stevens's abstract reflection and poetic structure. (Her rewriting concords with Thylias Moss's “Reconsideration of the Blackbird,” in which she writes: “Problem: No one's in love with the blackbirds. / Solution: Paint them white, call them visions, everyone will want one.”) Hayes and Senior apply the principles of cannibalistic poetics to their rewritings of Stevens, and by metonymic extension, to their rewriting/writing into the blanks or white spaces of American poetics. They show that poetry is not impartial: it tells the history of national culture.96
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/complitstudies.51.1.0018 journal-article-10.5325_complitstudies.51.1.0018.xml

Journal Title: Comparative Literature Studies
Article Title: Book Review
Publisher: Verso
Issue: complitstudies.51.3.issue-3
Date: 9 1, 2013
Author(s): Damrosch David
Abstract: Throughout her book, Apter makes a forceful case for the need to understand the “world” in World Literature as both politically and linguistically fraught, and she echoes Gayatri Spivak and others in arguing that World Literature's “ethic of liberal inclusiveness … often has the collateral effect of blunting political critique” (41). As she says in a chapter on “Dispossessive Collectivism,” World Literature needs to be more than a project of “curatorial salvage,” a mere museum of words without borders that “gathers up swaths of literary culture deemed vulnerable to extinction and performs preservational intervention” (326). Her pursuit of these themes takes Apter from the novels of Pynchon and DeLillo to the work of the Palestinian/American conceptual artist Emily Jacir, and the volume includes a cautionary essay on “Checkpoints and Sovereign Borders” (99–114) and a brief but suggestive chapter on the problematic extension of European historical categories to areas far beyond Europe (“Eurochronology and Periodicity,” 57–69). In terms of translation studies, Apter offers a counter-narrative to the celebratory accounts by practitioners such as Edith Grossman or David Bellos (19–20), giving extended exegeses of work on translation theory by Derrida and several thinkers in his wake, and exploring case studies including the complex history of an English translation of Madame Bovaryby Karl Marx's daughter Eleanor, later revised by Paul and Patricia de Man.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/complitstudies.51.3.0504 journal-article-10.5325_complitstudies.51.3.0504.xml

Journal Title: The F. Scott Fitzgerald Review
Article Title: “Nature and Optics in the Great Gatsby.”
Publisher: Penguin
Issue: fscotfitzrevi.12.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 1989
Author(s): Salmose Niklas
Abstract: In the end, Gatsby's dream dies in a manifestation of every man's past, rather than one individual's fate; the conclusion prepares us for a transcendence from an individual fate to a universal one, from a presence to a distance, creating a microcosm of the themes of the entire novel: “the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room” (134). The reader, together with the key characters of the book, travel by car toward the verge of destiny, in the most brilliant prolepsis of the novel: “So we drove toward death through the cooling twilight” (136). The party is over; enter the hangover.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/fscotfitzrevi.12.1.0067 journal-article-10.5325_fscotfitzrevi.12.1.0067.xml

Journal Title: Interdisciplinary Literary Studies
Article Title: “History and Tragedy.”
Publisher: Harper and Row
Issue: intelitestud.16.2.issue-2
Date: 9 1, 1971
Author(s): Eze Chielozona
Abstract: If Dekuah signifies the unwillingness to live, or reminds us of the Frankenstein syndrome, as suggested above, it is no surprise that the child in the poem immediately announces that he is not Dekuah; he has not come to die. Emphasizing the singularity of his existence, his will to live, he says, “I've never been born before,” and then goes on to announce what he is and what he desires. “My name is Nehklon / Let me live.” Of particular relevance is the shift from the negative declaration “I am not” to a positive one, “I am.” In this linguistic switch, the poet signals a deeper moral and existential consequence. In this shift from a reactionary attitude to life to one that is proactive, Jabbeh Wesley brings the challenges of life affirmation to the consciousness of her readers. Through Nehklon, she enables us to imagine people taking charge of their lives, as Primo Levi does in his “If This Is a Man.” It is therefore not only Nehklon who pleads; all Liberians plead for a chance to live, for a fair share in life's bounty. There is nothing to be happy about in the remembrance of the war's violence; there is no happy ending for the narrative other than the hope that people might be allowed to live and to thrive. People are not Dekuahs; they have not come to die.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/intelitestud.16.2.0282 journal-article-10.5325_intelitestud.16.2.0282.xml

Journal Title: Journal of Africana Religions
Article Title: What Is Africa to Me?
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jafrireli.1.1.issue-1
Date: 1 1, 2013
Abstract: The kind of sophisticated geographical historical methodology employed by Fernand Braudel comes to mind here. Braudel in his classic The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip IIintroduces us to three strata of time. The first is thelongue durée, “a history whose passage is almost imperceptible, that of man in relationship to his environment, a history in which all change is slow, a history of constant repetition, ever-recurring cycles.” The second is a social history of societies, civilizations, and states. The third is what one of his colleagues has calledl'histoire evenementielle, “that is the history of events, surface disturbances … a history of brief, rapid, nervous fluctuations, by definition ultra-sensitive.” Braudel's methodology works well for the work he accomplished; the Mediterranean Sea is a5 longue duréeand the life and times of Philip II is the structure of the history of events with the various Mediterranean states and societies forming the second structure of social histories.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jafrireli.1.1.0091 journal-article-10.5325_jafrireli.1.1.0091.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: American Continental Philosophy in the Making:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Yet I think I speak for most of the witnesses when I retell this little episode with some affection and amusement, in remembrance of a man who had much more important things to give us than a proper label for what we were trying to do. Moreover—and this is the point I want to stress here—except maybe for William Earle, Gurwitsch's objection was not treated as ideological or as calling upon us to chose then and there between pure and adulterated phenomenology. Nor did anyone with a primary interest in neo-Marxism, critical social theory, classical pragmatism, or existentialized Thomism see themselves as excluded by either proposed label. And this, I want to say, was typical of SPEP meetings from the very beginning. The stress was on the things themselves—especially those things that the larger philosophical world ignored, distorted, or explained away—and not on their One True Articulation.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0108 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0108.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: The Plight of Ethics
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: We live in the ethical-political bind between Kantian universality and Levinasian singularity where, without yet having learned the lessons of either, we all too easily identify Us with right and good and Them with wrong and evil. This applies just as much to those of us who, from our comfortable living rooms and privileged academic positions, identify with the victims and the oppressed, with Troy Davis, as it does to those who wave flags of victory over the corpses of their enemies or order the execution of another poor black man sentenced to death. The plight of ethics, then, is not simply figuring out how to relearn our primary school lesson to share with others in the reciprocity of equality as like for like— no small feat in itself—but also trying to figure out what it would mean to risk sharing the planet with those with whom we do not even share a world. The greater risk that comes from this Kantian legacy, the obligation or duty left to us from modern ethics, is to learn to welcome those we fear, those we hate, even those we call enemy, by pledging ourselves to a radicial abolitionism of death penalities whatever form they may take.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0118 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0118.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Phenomenology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: But consider the referents when I say, “Come here, I want to show you a gorilla,” “Come here, I want to show you a human being,” “Here look at this beautiful woman,” “Look at this hunk of a man,” and so forth, all of which feature properties. Now consider a quite different display: “Come here, I want to show you a person.” What are we here looking for? How does it differ from an individual human being? Granted that we in fact use personas synonymous withhuman being, are we here merely displaying an individual human being or instance of the kind called “human”? Consider the resistance in saying, “Come here, I want to show you a Barak Obama.” We might, of course, have in mind a political style or character and thus refer to a constellation of properties. But we would not be referring to the person, Barak Obama, certainly not to what he refers to when he says “I,” but, for example, to a type, a certain sort of politician. 30
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0222 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0222.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Critical Theory
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: I had spent the summer of 1960 studying Greek and working as a laundry truck driver for the Alert Laundry Company, who's cliental lived in the ghetto that surrounded the University of Chicago. That summer, of the thirteen laundry trucks of the Alert Laundry Company, twelve were robbed. Mine wasn't. I got to know everybody, including the robbers, who gave me a pass. That summer marked the beginning of an education that allowed me to see, firsthand, the real injustice of America, which in the course of events led to the civil rights movement, whose northern base was Chicago. Looking back over the events of my life I can say that although I was born in Iowa, I grew up in Chicago. Clearly, the University of Chicago provided me with a dual education: one that made it possible for me to earn academic degrees and another that afforded a set of experiences that transformed my life. As a result of all that, the changing times and the Chicago experience, much to the chagrin of those who hired me at Boston College, I began to teach a number of courses on social phenomenology (Schutz), attempting to do a kind of social philosophy, which, of course, was a very respectable thing, still being done today. Then in 1971 I went to Germany to perfect my German and by accident ended up at the University of Marburg (Phillips Universität Marbug), the most radical university in Germany at the time. There I was appropriately intimidated, mainly by German students, regarding my knowledge of political philosophy as it related to the most celebrated figure of the day, Karl Marx. I returned to Boston at the end of that summer harboring a passion for finding out what Marx was about. After reading several books on Marx I decided that he couldn't be as bad as his representatives portrayed him, and I started reading the man himself. Like many others I was seduced, converted, overwhelmed, transformed by the encounter, which led to a long struggle with the man and his work from which I never fully re~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0291 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0291.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: French Poststructuralism
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: “What we call action,” Lingis writes, “is not simply an adjustment to compensate for what passes and passes away…. Our action arises upon an interruption, a break, of the continuity of operations, biological, physiological, and also laborious, that go on in us.” He continues, Everything—not just the chance encounter of sperm and egg that brought about the existence of one Nancy Gilvonio but all life—is utterly improbable. Reason—“the reasoning, reckoning intellect that identifies possibilities on the basis of past regularities” (LingisPhilosophers of history, whether reactionary or radical, see actions as shaped by values…. They see in the driving force of an action the momentum of accumulated skills and habits. They explain an action out of an evolving environment…. But our action … is an interruption of the continuous dialectic of history, an awakening from the drowsy murmur of the semiotics of a culture. (1999, 205) 1999, 209–10)—is confounded, and one finds oneself in the sheer happening of whatever happens. Once a woman lost her brother, fell in love, joined a movement, gave birth, and languished in prison. A man who loved her stormed a building, took hostages, wrote a letter, and died at the hands of a SWAT team. It was all highly improbable. Once you and I wrote a dissertation, accepted a job offer, attended a conference. All that is highly improbable as well. Once there was a star on which there were animals who invented philosophy. And it was all very, very improbable. In Al Lingis's work, improbability and the innocence of becoming become palpable.

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Philosophy of Technology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: What of technology, particularly for Continentals? For those dominating philosophy of science, technologies are merely “applied science,” derived and dependent upon science. But again in academia, in parallel with popular existentialism, there was another disjunct. The technology guru being everywhere read was Herbert Marcuse, One Dimensional Man(1964)—and lurking behind him but not yet widely read concerning technology, Martin Heidegger. Note that this interpretation of technology was not that of applied science but that of Technology gone autonomous, become that which encloses and overwhelms the human. This was to be, for long stretches of time, the dominant SPEP “technology,” just as existentialism had been its earliest philosophy.

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Ethics and Religion in Continental Philosophy
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: I said that the earlier contrast of idol and icon and the later fivefold analysis of the saturated phenomenon were of special interest in the present context. How so? Quite unexpectedly, we discover that both analyses invoke the concept of an inverted intentionality. In the experience of the icon (as distinct from the idol) we find “a nearly perfect inversion” of the intentionality that constitutes the idol as such: “If man, by his gaze, renders the idol possible, in reverent contemplation of the icon, on the contrary, the gaze of the invisible, in person, aims at man…. [T]he icon opens in a face that gazes at our gazes … offering its spectacle to be transgressed—not to be seen, but to be venerated…. [T]he intention here issues from infinity…. [H]ere our gaze becomes the optical mirror of that at which it looks only by finding itself more radically looked at.” 38

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: Recovering Hyperbole:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: philrhet.45.4.issue-4
Date: 12 1, 2012
Abstract: What I am suggesting is that it is the less obvious, nuanced hyperboles that are significant and that deserve further critical attention, for example, philosophical, discursive, prophetic, ironic, or polemical hyperboles. What I show in discussing some of these types of hyperbole is that hyperbole can and does operate as more than just a simplistic, intentional, and commonplace exaggeration. According to Jean-Pierre Mileur, Paul de Man “suggests, variously, that hyperbole is the trope of tropes, the trope that governs the formation of tropes, the trope that governs the transformation of tropes into texts or, most important, that hyperbole is the (non)trope that exceeds the limits of all tropologies, the situation out of and against which tropes arise and are generalized into texts, the shape of our being-in-the-world, not reducible to rhetorical terms” (1986, 125). Mileur's more extreme claims about de Man's thought regarding hyperbole as a (non)trope or as irreducible to rhetorical terms notwithstanding, what Mileur may be driving at in this audacious, perhaps exaggerated, statement is the significance that hyperbole has as a movement within discourse and in relation to the interpretation of meaning. It is a figure of thought that can highlight the limits of figuration and representation (Bloom 2003), operate as a vehicle for the sublime (Marvick1986), destabilize norms and conventions, and encourage active reflection on “the different ways in which meaning is constructed and communicated” (Ettenhuber2007, 210).
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.45.4.0406 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.45.4.0406.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: “Reading the Past against the Grain: The Shape of Memory Studies.”
Publisher: University of Chicago Press
Issue: philrhet.46.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 1998
Abstract: Ricoeur identifies three ways in which the mediating function of mimesis 2operates in the configuration of narratives. First, configuration mediates between the individual event and the story as a whole by assigning an event a place of significance in the unfolding of a plot. Let us take, for instance, a book from the aforementioned Americans All series. Lillie Patterson's 1970Martin Luther King, Jr.: Man of Peace, which was awarded the first Coretta Scott King Book Award for African American children's literature, begins with an anecdote from King's childhood. This story narrates King's supposed first encounter with the “wall” of racism. When he enters school, his white friends are no longer allowed to play with him. He persists in seeking their company but is rebuffed: “Finally, their mother tried to tell Martin why. ‘You see, you are colored and they are white’” (Patterson 1970, 10). Unsatisfied, Martin goes to his own mother, who explains the history of slavery and its effects on their lives. She concludes by reminding her son that despite this past, “You are as good as anyone” (Patterson 1970, 10–12). As the opening scene, this vignette both introduces King as a child (creating an identificatory link with readers) and frames the remaining story about a confident man who worked to break down that “wall” of racism. Second, configuration joins and relates disparate aspects of the story, including various agents, actions, motivations, and outcomes. Patterson's text, for example, emphasizes both King's personal ambition and his cooperation with others. Members of his family play a key role, and the appearance of his wife, Coretta Scott, warrants an entire chapter (Patterson 1970, 33–38). Their marriage is represented not as mere love story but as the collaboration between two powerful social agents. The narrator explains that in accepting marriage to King, “Coretta decided to join the young minister and share his dream” (Patterson 1970, 37). Finally, configura~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.46.2.0182 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.46.2.0182.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Dilemmas and Delusions
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Wixson Christopher
Abstract: Along the same lines, in the preface to Man and Superman, he draws a distinction between two states of corporeal infirmity. The first, what he calls “the true joy of life,” results from “the being used for a purpose recognized by yourself as a mighty one; the being thoroughly worn out before you are thrown on the scrap heap, the being a force of nature.” The second is engendered by a failure of will and perspective, producing “a feverish selfish little clod of ailments and grievances, complaining that the world will not devote itself to making you happy.” Scholars and biographers have taken both views of Shaw. Countless testimonies of friends and acquaintances as well as innumerable pronouncements by GBS himself laud the extraordinary vibrancy of the “active young revolutionist” following his typical schedule of prolific writing and speech giving.22 At the same time, Shaw's private diaries are replete with meticulous physiological self-examination, documenting his crippling headaches as well as myriad illnesses, injuries, changes in weight and appetite, and suspected symptoms. Robert Brustein attributes “a kind of Swiftian disgust at the human body and its functions” to the playwright, while Sally Peters pathologizes his interest in health, arguing its origin in latent psychosis, specifically an obsessive fear of contagion.23 His commitment to vegetarianism, teetotalism, and Jaegerism, she argues, was founded as much upon hygienic paranoia as moral principle: “Fueled by a “desperate revulsion from body and biology[,] … Shaw's was an ever-lasting defense against dirt, poison, and contamination[,] whatever symbolized to him the form-destroying potencies of existence.”24 In any case, the vexed body, on its way to evolutionary elimination, assiduously preoccupied Shaw, and matters of personal and public wellness remained an idée fixe until the end of his life.25
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0001.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Bernard Shaw and Paul Ricoeur
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Einsohn Howard Ira
Abstract: Moreover, the astute logician in Shaw sees the newborn child as a commissioned envoy of divinity, whether that divinity is understood as the Judeo-Christian God, the Shavian Life Force, or the equivalent in some other belief system. Using the Christian sacrament of Baptism as a dispositive case in point, Shaw, always the cogent syllogist, argues that “if God is the Father of all men, and if the child is the father to man, it follows then that the true representative of God at the christening is the child itself.” Hence, from Shaw's considered viewpoint, if we seek the Kingdom of Heaven, we need not scour the galaxy frenetically. Instead, we should look no further than ourselves, for in each of us dwell effervescent particles of the same numen that breathes life into inert matter. In sum, for Shaw, every conception is immaculate,42 and every child is a living incarnation of the primeval goodness that bathes the universe.43
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0133 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0133.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Rhetorical Function of Utopia:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Perhaps the resemblance between rhetorical invention and utopia is best illustrated in Plato's dialogue Phaedrus. Plato disparaged rhetoric in his earlier philosophical writings, particularly in theGorgias, where he claims that rhetoric is nothing but flattery; it panders to the public and works only to have power for the moment, by showing off with glamour and stirring up desire. For Plato, rhetoric, like the concept of utopia to most twentieth-century Marxists, was an unrealistic waste of time and a useless dream of escape. But in his later works, Plato changed his mind about rhetoric, just as Marcuse changed his about the usefulness of utopia as a concept in history. In thePhaedrus, Socrates is in love with the interlocutor in his dialogue, a young man who is intelligent but easily swayed by shows of verbal/symbolic skill and emotional power—the very propagandistic techniques that Marcuse would scrutinize in the need for a reeducation of desire. Socrates, voicing Plato's mature understanding of the function of rhetoric when it is used for the betterment of society, tells the young Phaedrus that “the function of oratory is to influence men's souls.” For the wisest of orators, who would be the best of political and cultural leaders, the art of rhetoric is one that is informed by long study of human nature but also by a divine inspiration. The inventor in this type of rhetorical work is possessed with a kind of love, a divine Eros, by which he or she leads the multitudes to the good, tempered by self-control. In effect, he conceives of rhetoric as a kind of erotic love that seeks to persuade the beloved (that is, the audience, whether an individual or the social collective in a state). The function of Plato's rhetoric in the30 Phaedrus, like Marcuse's and Bloch's function of utopia, is to use imagination and emotion to lead constituents toward belief in a fuller humanity, a true expression of the good in human nature.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.1.0113 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.1.0113.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Meta-Utopian Metatext:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.2.issue-2
Date: 10 1, 2012
Abstract: As he pledged at the end of A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, Joyce has succeeded inforging(both creating and counterfeiting) his world. Daedalus the master architect is also his own son Icarus, the overreacher destined for oblivion. This is the Joyce who has “forged out his sentences”—the pseudo-messianic author of a “piously forged” work. If this work is a transcendental epic, a narrative of nationhood, then it is an “epical forged cheque”—“every dimmed letter of it … a copy … the last word in stolentelling.”127 This indeed is Derrida's forged simulacrum: the “shamwork”128 that reveals that129 Finnegans Wakewas always, as its title announces, a massiveF … ake.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.2.0472 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.2.0472.xml

Journal Title: Cultural Critique
Article Title: “Biopolitics: From Surplus Value to Surplus Life.”
Publisher: Princeton University Press
Issue: culturalcritique.86.issue-2014
Date: 1 1, 1996
Abstract: Examining Agamben's reception of Hannah Arendt, and especially The Human Condition, in his theorization of biopolitics, this essay argues thatHomo Sacer I, by identifying Arendt with a quasi-Straussian “political philosophy,” fails to acknowledge the complexity of her conception of history. Far from simply affirming the normative force of classical political categories, Arendt regards these as emerging from a living power of distinction that thinking, by showing the historical process that brings about the effacement of these distinctions, seeks to bring into view. Nevertheless, Arendt's conception of history is not without contradiction: while arguing that metaphysics went astray by subordinating praxis to poiesis, her very account of history suggests that this subordination is inevitable, since only a “poetic,” indeed violent, act of making a distinction can distinguish praxis from poiesis. Precisely this problem lies at the center of Agamben's early engagement with Arendt inThe Man without Content.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5749/culturalcritique.86.2014.0001 journal-article-10.5749_culturalcritique.86.2014.0001.xml
